channel.title: Reflection when finding a method

item.title: Reflection when finding a method
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

client.java:9892: variable theMethod might not have been initialized Method theMethod = clazz.getDeclaredMethod(varString, th eMethod.getParameterTypes());

You can’t do that silly :D. theMethod.getParameterTypes()…
When you call that, theMethod isn’t initialized yet. So it’d be like doing null.get…
You’d just get a null pointer. That’s why the compiler catches it.

Tch tch…why did Jagex hire you

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection when finding a method
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

You should definetly be using BCEL, reflection is a piece of shit when you get into actually finding methods/fields/anything.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection when finding a method
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

When using reflection to find a specific method by name how would you go about getting it to just find the parameters autmatically

this is what i have right now and it will find the method if it has no parameters but wont if it has parameters, would i have to first get all the methods then just compare?

try{ Class clazz = this.getClass(); Method theMethod = clazz.getDeclaredMethod(varString, new Class[0]); printTo("Cmd Method: "+theMethod.getName()); s = s.replace("@"+varString, " "); }catch (Throwable e) { System.err.println(e); printTo("Cmd UH OH"); }
i tried to do it like this:

[code] try{

		Class clazz = this.getClass();
		Method theMethod = clazz.getDeclaredMethod(varString, theMethod.getParameterTypes());
		printTo("Cmd Method: "+theMethod.getName());
		s = s.replace("@"+varString, " ");
	}catch (Throwable e) {
        	System.err.println(e);
	printTo("Cmd UH OH");
     	}[/code]

but get this error:

client.java:9892: variable theMethod might not have been initialized Method theMethod = clazz.getDeclaredMethod(varString, th eMethod.getParameterTypes()); ^

Read full topic
